text: Hi everybody, welcome to another episode, I'm Mike Monticello.
I'm Emily Thomas.
And I'm Steve Oick.
So today we're going to be focused on the redesigned 2024 Chevrolet Traverse.
These are going to be our first impressions and these impressions are based on a model
that we bought for anonymously from a local dealer as we do with every vehicle that goes
to our test program.
So this one will be going through our test program for those that don't know what the
Traverse is.
It's a three row mid-sized SUV slots between the Equinox and the large Otaho and Chevy's
SUV lineup.
And just for background on the Traverse, it was a solid competitor.
You know, one of those SUVs is it's great at doing really good things, but you know, it's
not like a wonderful vehicle to drive, but it's just a really good all around family SUV.
Nothing stood out about it being bad, nothing stood out about it like it wasn't like an
amazing handler or anything like that, but just a really good SUV.
And as such, it ranked typically, you know, toward the upper reaches of the category
in our ratings.
For 2024, it gets new exterior styling, a new infotainment screen, but the biggest changes
under the hood.
So the V6 is gone.
You can't get that anymore.
The only engine is a turbocharged four-cylinder, and we're going to have a lot to say about
that through our discussion.
So we bought a 2024 Chevrolet Traverse LT All-Wheel Drive.
The LT is the second tier trim.
So it has a 328 horsepower 2.5 liter turbocharged four-cylinder.
It's a bit automatic transmission.
We got the optional All-Wheel Drive.
It comes standard with front-wheel drive.
And along with a few options, including the enhanced driving package, which brings GM's
supercruise, enhanced reactive driving assistance system, plus the $1,395 destination fee
that Chevy charges on ultra-versus.
Total cost of a test vehicle is $49,460.
So three-row mid-size SUV, family vehicle.
I can't think of two people more qualified to talk about a vehicle like this.
They're here at ATC at the Auto Test Center because you both have young families.
I would think this would be a vehicle that would be certainly the target audience, I
think.
Yeah.
But even though it would make sense to talk about second-third-row room, maybe cargo space,
maybe how the child seats fit, we're going to start with the engine because I think it
could be a deal breaker for some people.

The vehicle is generally quite otherwise, and thankfully the engine settles into the

Yeah, I think it replaces the V6 quite well, actually.
It really has pretty good power.
It has no turbo lag, which you may expect from having a four-cylinder turbo.
The transmission shifts nice and smoothly, and I mean, it has this linear power delivery.
I think the engine itself and the transmission it's made it to is pretty good.
It's executed pretty well.

I'll give it that.

I appreciate that like all those bends and turns, country roads, you have a decent amount

This suspension is tuned pretty well.

They help protect you in a crash.

An end of trip reminder, which will give you a uses door logic.

The second type of system goes beyond that and incorporates occupant sensing and it will
actually detect rear occupants in the vehicle.

So, our first question comes from James from Tampa, Florida.
James says, during Hurricane Helene, there were reports of Tesla's catching fire due to
flooding in the Tampa area.
The local fire chief warned people not to drive any electric vehicle that had been flooded
until you can get it inspected.
Is this a Tesla-only problem?
Are all EV susceptible to this?
Are hybrid cars with lithium-ion batteries subject to this problem?
So, Steve, I'm going to throw this to you.
What did you find out about this?
Yeah.
I talked to Big John and our amazing auto tech team about this.
And I asked, what do they think about flooded cars like this?
Well, I found out it's not a Tesla-only problem.
It's actually the potential for flooding the battery packs is there for all high voltage
batteries.
That includes hybrids, plug-in hybrids, and EVs.
And really, the issue is when there's water intrusion into the battery case, and the
biggest issue about this is when there's salt water.
Salt is like...
It's corrosive.
Corrosive.
And it really conducts electricity, and that's when it starts to cause problems and light
things on fire.
So to answer the question here is, yes, you should always get it checked by a mechanic.
And that's in general.
That's for all cars.
I mean, cars don't like water.
So even if you have an internal combustion engine, there could be a lot of other issues
with wiring harnesses and electronics in the car that are no good.
You really want someone professional to take the car apart and see that everything is
dry or be able to dry everything out.
And even then, they're telling me, the auto-tech team said, there's still a chance that you
won't dry everything out, and there could still be problems down the line.
So this is a huge issue, and yes, for battery packs, it is a fire risk.
And we have a lot of other stories on www.couseraborce.org about flood related with vehicles,
whether it's how to avoid buying a flood damage car or the dangers of driving on flooded
streets.
We have a lot of stories up on www.couseraborce.org about that.
So please check that out.
